reviewText:
I've had ClusterPuck for a few months and have played about 20 hours of it before it's launch on Steam. All of those hours in multi-player - so I cannot speak about the newly added 1 player challenge mode added for Steam launch.

ClusterPuck is a really great local multiplayer game - it's a load of fun to play, and it is even fun to say. The more friends and controllers you can get, the better. We play with 4 controllers - so usually 2 v 2, or we play the 4 of us vs 4 cpu opponents. We have an absolute blast, I can only imagine how much fun this game is with 8 controllers and 4 v 4 action!

It looks a lots like a simple top down air hockey table where each player controls a puck and each team tries to score goals using the only ball. There are no fouls and no referee, meaning you can barge, block and push your opponents. There are spikes, bouncing obstacles and speed ups, all adding extra craziness to the action. Table layouts which first seem impossible get a lot easier with a bit of practice - but the table with just 2 goals and no obstacles is probably still our most played table. I would recommend a big screen or a projector for playing ClusterPuck too, as there is a lot going on when there are 8 players, and the screen zooms out to take in all the action.

If you have the controllers and the friends, then ClusterPuck is one KICK ♥♥♥ game. It's joined MarioKart and Towerfall as one of the ever-presents when we meet up to play games. Highly recommended is you're in to local multi-player gaming.

reviewText:
I've been playing Clusterpuck since it was in early development, and I can confidently say that it's my all-time favorite sports game. The controls are crazy simple (2 buttons and a joystick) so that anyone can learn to play quickly, but advanced players can find and develop strategies that add a lot of complexity to the game.

My group of friends and I have gotten really competitive as a result of Clusterpuck, and I wouldn't be surprised if it ended up becoming an eSport as it is perfectly balanced and involves a lot of skill and strategy.

If I had one complaint, it would be that connecting 8 controllers to a laptop is a bit of a hassle. If you buy this, be sure to pick up a USB hub or a wireless adapter for Xbox 360 controllers.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Being a total idiot i bought this game before reading that it was local only, thinking that i could play it over skype with my girlfriend.. To be honest, by that point I'd already fired up the game to see what it was about. The menus are so well designed and easy to navigate, they look gorgeous too. I am a graphic design student who likes minimalist design heaps and i have to say, i would have paid the full price just to stare at the menus, they are that aestetically pleasing.

Reading about  the game i found out it had a single player, from what i could find, this was a challenge mode.. I gave this a go and found it rather fun, however i just wanted to play a game.. I decided to search the forums seeing wether the regular matches had bots to which i found out they did. I couldnt work out how to get bots into the game. My only criticism is when you first start out it isnt immediately obvious how to start a game when choosing teams, i think this is just me being dumb but ohhhh welll xD When i workied it out, it makes perfect sense.

From browsing the achievements i saw there was one for a 10 minute long game.. That is the longest time limit you can have on a game, I decided- why not!! :D There are a lot of maps, from traditional hockey/football(soccer) style maps to totally ridiculous deathtraps and mazes. All are very fun to play. You can have up to 9 bots if you are playing solo and you can even pit yourself 1v9 (nothanks).

When i worked out how to navigate the next menu, it got me to choose a map and then assign bots before i could start. It really is idiot proof (except from me.. I'm just dumb). This game was well worth the price and to make that even better, it was on launch sale!! As of yet i haven't met any bugs either, which is strange as the game is only 2 days old.. Most definitely reccomend this!! Congratulations to the devs for coming up with such a fun and replayable time waster. It truely is beautiful and it handles a treat!!

reviewText:
If you have a few friends to play this game with locally, pick this game up! It is a great party game, and if you have eight controllers, than everyone can play and yell and holler at each other in one of the best non-sport sport games I've ever played! When starting out with new players, play on the Competitive" Maps as there are no traps on these maps and this allows everyone to get a feel for the game. Move onto the more intense maps if you really want to create a proper cluster of swears and jeers.

The challenges are a nice distraction and do help get a better understanding of the feel of the game.

recommended: is a top-down simplified hockey game.  You can create a profile (or multiple ones if you have family/friends who'd like to play) and choose a unique symbol/icon with which to identify yourself.  After that

reviewText: This one is hard for me to review, and the only reason i gave it a yes because the game itself is so much fun. I LOVE this game. I'v owned this game for a while now, and I've logged at least 10+ hours on it before it make the jump to steam. The game itself is a fun arcade style sports multiplayer game that wouldnt feel too out of place on the N64, If you have at least two friends that you could consistently play it with, it's might be worth a buy. Its not as much fun solo, and the lack of online multiplayer causes me to seriously hesitate recommending the game in its current state. but they have added in a challenge mode which makes it slightly more exciting on your own, but it took me an hour or two to complete and the replay value is not very high for this perticular mode. Worth a buy? If you have 2+ freinds who love exciting couch multiplayer sports games that will have you yelling and screaming over epic defeats and comebacks, then yes. If you are primarily an online player, or do not enjoy local co-op, then no.

reviewText: Great game if you have 4 poeple to play with also supports up to 8 controllers. Me and my nephews had a great time. Ai is pretty good. If you need to add one or 2. You can setup how ever many you want up to 10 players in all. you can even co-op vs a team of a.i.  A.i. has 3 different settings. easy, medium, and hard. Not really a good 1v1 game since once a player gets past the other one all they have to do is drive the puck into the others goal with nothing in their way to stop them. It is still playable with 2 humans just have to add some bots, or enjoy the battle leading up to getting the puck past the other player. There are several maps with some features such as spikes,speed boosters, and bouncers that will affect your player if you hit them, these maps may make it more playable in a 1v1 environment. Overall I definitely recommend this game if you have 4 players or more and It's not bad with odd amounts because you can add bots. Don't read  too much into the 1v1 complaint I made, just making sure if you buy it you intend to play with a few extra players. It does have a single player challenge/ camapaign also.\n\nAs of 2016.. no release of talked about update on forum.. also with windows 10  and xbox one controllers do not function correctly. Seems to be a unity issue also.. cuase I ahve several games that all use unity and have same issue player turns to left even when not inputting any input. It can be fixed by devs... As Knight squad is agame that the dev has fixed this issue with. Be cautious if you do not have xbox 360 controllers. Do not buy if using windows 10 and have xbone controllers.

reviewText:
No online multiplayer and the keyboard controls are brutal (doesn't auto-rotate with WASD like it does for controllers).

However, if you have got a few controllers (we use DualShock 4) and can get some people to come over, this game is an absolute blast. It's a simple game. Every player has the same stats and there's only three moves: tackle, shoot, and charge shot. I'm not even sure when to use the charge shot. Add in some environmental hazards like bottomless pits, spikes, reflectors and turbo plates and it takes the game to another level. The computers kick our ♥♥♥ even on easy but I'm not so sure if they are smart or if we really suck.

My wife said that's the best dollar you ever spent.""

reviewText:
Note: This is my first review and I purchased Clusterpuck 99 for (ironically enough) $0.99.
Clusterpuck 99 has a lot of elements that make it an ideal game to pick up and play if you regularly play video games with people on your couch. It boasts the rare ability to have 8 players play at once (if you have the controllers and USB ports to pull it off, mind you), and what it lacks in graphics, a sluggish pace, and the glaring error of no online multiplayer it tries to makes up for with its simple and engaging concept and gameplay. This simple game (with its ~4 controls) regularly creates the memorable moments that most people look for in local multiplayer games. You know, the ones where people are laughing, yelling, or high-fiving because of momentary displays of skill, chaos, or brilliance.

In my time with the game I have found that the AI, even on hard" difficulty
date: are very little challenge and it is often best to give them an extra man or two to keep things stressful in the most delightful way. Friendly A.I. rarely
hoursPlayed: pass the puck which is frustrating but the developers explained that having a "call for the puck" button would radically change the game and its feel and I agree with them. However
voteText: it does make playing this game alone vastly inferior to playing with a buddy. A hell of a lot of fun can be had when you're outnumbered by A.I. and have to work together to overcome their quantity with the quality of your play.\n\nIt is frustratingly easy to over and/or under-pursue the puck and if you've played the EA Sports NHL titles
helpfulPercent: there is almost no element of the puck "magnetizing" to you if you are in proximity to it
votesHelpful: you must make contact with the puck to possess it. This takes some getting used to
votesTotal: but it is by no means a deal breaker in regards to the feel of the game.\nFor the most part I play on the "competitive" levels because I find that there is more than enough chaos without boost squares
column16: but the game does feature a nice variety of levels. The zanier levels are good fun if you want to escape the feel of air hockey and sate your hunger to murder opponents by checking them into spiky death balls (it never gets old). The fact that there is a level editor supposedly on the way makes this one of those little-known games that sincerely deserves your attention.\n\nWith all of that being said
column17: I would not have paid $10 for the game because of the lack of online multiplayer and how much there is left to be desired in regards to some of the controls
column20: when the next update rolls around and adds the level editor
column22: and some other layers to this game it will easily be worth $10 if you regularly play with other people. If this one goes on sale again and if you're a local multiplayer aficionado
column23: give it a look and tell your friends to bring their controllers

reviewText:
It seems that the local multiplayer craze of the past few years has hit a peak recently. The genre has expanded out far and wide, and many games that would have been praised before are now plagued by obscurity and fighting amongst their talented competition. ClusterPuck 99 had been out for some time on Desura before hitting Steam at the beginning of 2015, one of five games bearing the genre’s tag released in the month of January. Steam in 2015 can be a vicious marketplace, which is why I was pleased to see ClusterPuck come out on Xbox One earlier this month. I had found the game on Desura ages ago, was eager to see what improvements had been made in the meantime, and what console specific fun I could have with the title. For better or worse, I found that ClusterPuck 99 has stuck to its roots as an insane multiplayer arena that requires swift aim and a roomful of friends.

NOTE: This review was written primarily using the Xbox One version of the game.

Want to know more? My full review is currently up for your perusal at TechRaptor.net http://techraptor.net/content/clusterpuck-99-review-air-hockey-evolved

reviewText: This is one of the most accessible local multiplayer games I've played on Steam: it's essentially digital air hockey. You only use the left analog stick and two face buttons, to pass and shoot the puck. When a game is this easy to play, it opens the door to non-gamers, who will love Clusterpuck. I consider this to be exclusively a local multiplayer game, as that is where it truly shines.\n\nAmazingly, Clusterpuck supports up to 8 players. I tried this out with friends and it was an absolute blast, and we have played with 8 players several times since then. Note that if you want to do this you will not only need 8 controllers but you will also need two Xbox 360 wireless dongles to facilitate the 8 controllers. The setup is a hassle but it if you go through the setup and have 8 friends to play with on a large screen, I think you will agree that it's worth it. We played this on a 120 projected display."
